importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Combs was arrested in September 2024, marking the beginning of a high-profile legal case that attracted global media attention.
The trial began in the summer of 2024, following his arrest, and drew widespread international media coverage.
The sentencing hearing took place in September 2024, where Combs expressed remorse and requested a lighter sentence.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from September 2024 to the sentencing hearing in September 2024 covered the trial and sentencing of Sean 'Diddy' Combs, forming the central timeline of the case.
The announcement of the appeal on October 21, 2025, indicates ongoing legal challenges and public interest in the outcome, reflecting continued relevance beyond the trial.

keyTakeAways: Sean 'Diddy' Combs, a prominent figure in the music industry, is appealing his conviction and 50-month prison sentence following a federal trial in 2024.
The conviction is for two counts of transportation to engage in prostitution, while he was acquitted of sex trafficking and racketeering charges.
Judge Arun Subramanian imposed a 50-month sentence, a $500,000 fine, and five years of probation, emphasizing accountability for abuse of women.
Combs expressed remorse during sentencing, acknowledging his actions as 'disgusting, shameful, and sick', and apologized to two women who testified against him.

The case centered on allegations that Combs used his influence to run a sex trafficking operation involving his girlfriends, including claims of forced 'hotel nights' with male escorts, particularly linked to his relationship with Cassandra Ventura and a woman identified as Jane.
Combs' legal team has formally notified the court of plans to appeal both the conviction and the sentence, signaling a continued legal and public battle.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Sean 'Diddy' Combs, a globally recognized music mogul, has been convicted of two counts of transportation to engage in prostitution and sentenced to 50 months in prison, a $500,000 fine, and five years of probation. While acquitted on charges of sex trafficking and racketeering, the conviction centers on allegations that Combs used his influence to coerce women into participating in 'freak-offs' with escorts, notably involving his relationships with Cassandra Ventura and a woman known as Jane. Combs expressed deep regret during sentencing, and his legal team has now formally announced plans to appeal both the conviction and the sentence, signaling a significant ongoing legal and public controversy.
title: Sean 'Diddy' Combs says he plans to appeal sentence and conviction
